        public static boolean hasOddCycle​(boolean[][] adjacencyMatrix,
                                  int vertices,
                                  int start)
        to detect odd cycles the starting vertex preferably chosen in a connected part for extra speed

        inspired by: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/check-graphs-cycle-odd-length/

        Parameters:
        adjacencyMatrix - the graph
        vertices - mumber of vertices of the graph
        start - starting vertex index
        Returns:
        true if an odd cycle exists, false otherwisw

      • colorRecursiveLargestFirst

        public static java.util.LinkedList<java.util.LinkedList<java.lang.Integer>> colorRecursiveLargestFirst​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer>[] adjacencyArrayList,
                                                                                                       java.util.LinkedList<java.util.LinkedList<java.lang.Integer>> solution,
                                                                                                       java.util.LinkedList<java.lang.Integer> candidates,
                                                                                                       java.util.LinkedList<java.lang.Integer> excluded,
                                                                                                       java.util.LinkedList<java.lang.Integer> alreadyColored)
        Recursive largest first algorithm
        Parameters:
        adjacencyArrayList - the graph
        solution - color sets containing vertices
        candidates - possible vertices to color with active color
        excluded - uncolored vertices that can't be colored with the active color
        alreadyColored - keeps track og already colored vertices
        Returns:
        the solution set

      • singleVertexSaturation

        public static int singleVertexSaturation​(boolean[][] adjacencyMatrix,
                                         int[] colorList,
                                         int vertexIndex)
        calculate the number of different colors among the colored vertices adjacent to a specified vertex example: if a vertex is adjacent to 4 vertices with colors [1, (no color), 1, 2] then the saturation is 2.
        Parameters:
        adjacencyMatrix - the graph
        colorList - the list containing current coloring
        vertexIndex - desired vertex
        Returns:
        degree of saturation

      • uncoloredSaturations

        public static int[] uncoloredSaturations​(boolean[][] adjacencyMatrix,
                                         int[] colorList)
        uses singleVertexSaturation to create a list with -1's if a vertex is colored in order to distinguish between unsaturated (0) and colored vertices (-1)
        Parameters:
        adjacencyMatrix - graph
        colorList - current list of colorings
        Returns:
        list with contents as described

      • uncoloredNotAdjacentSet

                                                                             int[] colorList,
                                                                             int vertex)
        Creates an ArrayList containing all vertex indices if vertices that are uncolored and not adjacent to the vertex specified
        Parameters:

        colorList - the current coloring
        vertex - the vertex for which the set is compiled
        Returns:
        the set described above

      • selectVertexDSATUR

        public static int selectVertexDSATUR​(int[] saturationList,
                                     int[] degreeList)
        highest saturation vertex is selected. if there are multiple higest, then the highest degree among them gets selected if the degrees are also equal, the vertex that was first in the list will just be selected.
        Parameters:
        saturationList - created based on current coloring
        degreeList - created at beginning of the program
        Returns:
        the index of the vertex to be colored

      • assignColorDSATUR

        public static int assignColorDSATUR​(boolean[][] adjacencyMatrix,
                                    int[] colorList,
                                    int vertex)
        The color assigning for a given vertex happens by first creating a set containing all unique colors(numbers) that are used by its adjacent vertices. if the size of that list is equal to the highest known color it follows directly that a new color is assigned. otherwise, we just pick the first/lowest number that it is not in the set.
        Parameters:
        adjacencyMatrix - the graph
        colorList - current coloring
        vertex - to color
        Returns:
        the color to use for coloring

      • isMColorable

        public static boolean isMColorable​(int[][] graph,
                                   int upperBound,
                                   int vertices)
        This function solves the m Coloring problem using Backtracking. It mainly uses graphColoringUtil() to solve the problem. It returns false if the m colors cannot be assigned, otherwise return true. Please note that there may be more than one solutions.

        based on: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/m-coloring-problem-backtracking-5/

        Parameters:
        upperBound - best upper bound so far
        vertices - order of the graph
        graph - the adjacency matrix
        Returns:
        whether a graph is colorable for the upper bound provided

      • showConflicts

        public static void showConflicts​(boolean[][] adjacencyMatrix,
                                 int[] colorlist)
        verifies that no colors are conflicting by iterationg over the adjacency matrix on one side of the diagonal creates a list of conflicts that has the conflicting elements
        Parameters:
        adjacencyMatrix - the graph
        colorlist - the coloring to be tested

      • maxIntValueOfArray

        public static int maxIntValueOfArray​(int[] array)
        Parameters:
        array - the array to analyze
        Returns:
        highest integer value in the array
